issues.description: The problem statement (and UML) require Farm to use a List<Animal> and explicitly instruct to initialize an ArrayList in the no-arg constructor. The solution implementation instead declares the collection as a Set<Animal> and initializes it as a HashSet (and the getter/setter use Set<Animal>). This is a structural mismatch: the field and its accessor types differ from the specified List/ArrayList, which can change ordering/duplication semantics and will confuse students about which collection type to implement and may cause tests that expect a List/ArrayList to fail.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution with the problem specification: change the Farm collection type to List<Animal>, import java.util.ArrayList and java.util.List, and initialize animals = new ArrayList<>(); update the getter/setter signatures to use List<Animal>. Alternatively, if Sets are intended pedagogically, update the problem statement/UML and template to explicitly require a Set/HashSet and explain the change to students. Prefer the first fix to preserve the current exercise description.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and textual instructions) requires the Farm to hold its animals as a List<Animal> implemented using an ArrayList and to initialize that ArrayList in the no-arg constructor. The solution implementation instead declares the collection as a Set<Animal> and initializes it with a HashSet. This is a mismatch in the identity of the collection type (List/ArrayList vs Set/HashSet) for the same conceptual entity 'the farm's animals' and can confuse students: they are instructed to use a List/ArrayList but the reference solution uses a different collection type and identifier, which changes available operations and expected behavior.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the collection type consistent across artifacts. Either (A) update the solution to use the same type the problem requires: declare 'private List<Animal> animals;' and initialize it with 'this.animals = new ArrayList<>();' (and update imports), or (B) if Set semantics were intentional, update the problem statement and template to specify 'Set<Animal>' / 'HashSet' so students are not instructed to implement an ArrayList but to use the Set instead. Prefer option (A) to match the explicit exercise instructions.
